description.summary: Japanese spider yokai that gains magical powers after 400 years. Shape-shifts into a beautiful woman to lure men, then traps them in silk and devours them.
description.full: The Jorōgumo is a spider yokai from Japanese folklore that gains supernatural powers upon reaching 400 years of age. Capable of transforming into a beautiful, seductive woman, the Jorōgumo lures unsuspecting men to isolated locations such as waterfalls, forests, or caves. Once ensnared by her beauty and charm, victims are trapped in her silk threads and devoured. The name translates to 'binding bride' or 'whore spider,' reflecting her deceptive and predatory nature. She may use children as bait, play musical instruments like the biwa, and in some accounts, can breathe fire. While appearing as an attractive woman, her true form is that of a giant spider.

coloration: As spider: dark, often black or brown
As woman: pale skin, dark hair typical

features.description: Appears as exceptionally attractive young woman
Sometimes spider legs visible even in human form
Possesses poisonous bite in spider form

physical.morphology: True form is giant spider. Can shape-shift into beautiful woman. Some accounts suggest hybrid forms or spider features bleeding through disguise.

abilities.description: Transform between giant spider and beautiful woman
Control and produce supernaturally strong silk threads for trapping
Irresistibly attractive to men, manipulative charm
Can play biwa (Japanese lute) to attract victims
Uses children or child-form to lure victims
Some accounts describe ability to breathe fire

patterns: Lures men with beauty and charm

range.description: Throughout Japan, particularly associated with waterfalls, forests, and remote areas.

origins.cultural_roots: Japanese yokai tradition and beliefs about animals gaining supernatural powers with age. Part of broader shape-shifter folklore.
origins.folklore_connections: Related to beliefs about yokai, animal transformation, and the danger of deceptive beauty.

timeline.significance: Folklore recorded in various collections and tales
Inclusion in major yokai and ghost story collections
Jorōgumo in manga, anime, and contemporary media

history.modern_era: Jorōgumo remain popular in Japanese culture through manga, anime, video games, and contemporary horror. Featured in various yokai-themed media.

notable_accounts.description: Famous tale of Jorōgumo at waterfall who lured and trapped men

notable_accounts.description: Tale of Jorōgumo who played biwa to attract victims

traditions: Wariness of beautiful women in remote areas
Moral warnings about lust and greed
stories: Men lured by beautiful women at waterfalls
Heroes who see through the disguise
Warnings about accepting invitations from strangers
folklore.beliefs: Jorōgumo represents the danger of deceptive appearances and unchecked lust. Teaches caution and awareness of predatory seduction.

indigenous.significance: Part of yokai tradition teaching moral lessons about deception, desire, and caution. Reflects cultural attitudes about feminine danger and predatory sexuality.
indigenous.sensitivity_note: Part of traditional Japanese cultural heritage and active folklore tradition.
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Recognize as legitimate cultural tradition with deep symbolic meaning. Understand within context of yokai folklore.

survival_techniques.description: Stay away from remote waterfalls, caves, and forests, especially alone
Watch for spider features, silk threads, or unnatural beauty in remote areas
If discovered in true form, can be killed by conventional means
Maintain awareness and resist supernatural charm

research.ongoing_studies: Contemporary study focuses on yokai folklore preservation, cultural symbolism, and comparative mythology.
